United States Department of State / Foreign relations of the United States. Conference at Quebec, 1944
			(1944)

 Conference documents and supplementary papers, pp. 385-480
			
 PDF (34.4 MB) 



Page 408


THE SECOND QUEBEC CONFERENCE
 D. ITALY
Roosevelt Papers
 Thee Secretary of State to the President 1
TOP SECRET WVASHINGTON, September 11, 1914.
 MEMORANDU3M FOR THE PRESIDENT
Subject: Proposals of British Chiefs of Staff for Disposition of
 Italian Overseas Territories
 I refer to your memorandum of April 28 2 in regard to certain pro-
posals of the British Chiefs of Staff for the future disposition of
Italian overseas territories.3
 In accordance with your request, I am enclosing a inemorandumn on
the subject which embodies the comments and recommendations of the
experts in the Department charged with these matters. While the con-
clusions drawn are in no sense final, they represent long and careful
study.
 I may add that the Joint Chiefs of Staff have expressed the view
that from the limited viewpoint of our national security, there are no
direct objections to the British proposals for the disposition of Italian
overseas territories since United States postwar military interests are
not directly affected.4 Fron the broader view of national and world-
 1 Sent by pouch to Quebec, where Roosevelt made the paper available to
Churchill and approved the mnaking of a copy for the British authorities.
See
post, p. 418, including fn. 2. The Department of State record copy of this
memoran-
duin is on file 865.014/4284-4.
 2 Not printed (865.014/4-2844).
 ' These proposals, as summarized by Hull in a mnemorandum to Roosevelt
drated
April 26, 1944, on the basis of information received from the United States
Mis-
sion at Algiers, were as follows:
 "1. Eritrea would be dismembered with the western highlands going
to the
Sudan and the highlands and Danakil coastal plain to Ethiopia. It is assumed
that the United Nations would not request a base at Mlassawa. A greater new
Somaliland would be created including Italian Somaliland, the northern frontier
district of Kenya and British and Ethiopian Ogaden Somaliland, the whole
preferably under British trusteeship.
 "2. Cyrenlaica would be an autonomous principality under Egyptian
suzerainity
with adequate safeguards for United Nations military requirements, including
facilities for air and naval bases in the Benghazi area. The offer of suzerainty
to
Egypt is considered a useful bargaining counter.
 "3. Tripolitania would be restored to Italy subject to guarantees
ofle demili-
tarization and retention by the British of the right to use Castel Benito
Airfield
as a staging point.
 "4. There would be frontier readjustments with the French except in
the
Fezzan area.
 "5. The Oweinat and Sarra triangle would be returned to the Sudan.
 "6. Castelrosso would go to Turkey and the remainder of the Dodecanese
to
Greece, subject to the right of Great Britain to use bases in Crete and other
facilities for bases in the islands, particularly Rhodes. Such facilities
might be
provided under some United Nations scheme.
 "7. Pantelleria and the Pelagians would be under effective British
control
either directly or through some general security scheme." (865.014/210)
 'See Foreign Relations, The Conferences at Malta and Yalta, 1945, p. 107,
fn. 4.
